title: Programming in Base R
text:
TreatmentPreBP <-c(130, 128, 116, 124, 133, 134, 118, 126, 114, 127, 141, 138, 128, 140, 137, 131, 120, 128, 139, 135)

TreatmentAfterBP <-c(114, 98, 113, 99, 107, 116, 113, 111, 119, 117, 101, 119, 130, 122, 106, 106, 124, 102, 117, 113)

TreatmentPreBP

 [1] 130 128 116 124 133 134 118 126 114 127 141 138 128 140 137 131 120 128 139
[20] 135

TreatmentAfterBP

 [1] 114  98 113  99 107 116 113 111 119 117 101 119 130 122 106 106 124 102 117
[20] 113






TreatmentSubject <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")
TreatmentSubject

 [1] "Subject_1"  "Subject_2"  "Subject_3"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_5" 
 [6] "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8"  "Subject_9"  "Subject_10"
[11] "Subject_11" "Subject_12" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[16] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"






TreatmentDiffBP <- (TreatmentAfterBP-TreatmentPreBP) 

TreatmentDiffBP

 [1] -16 -30  -3 -25 -26 -18  -5 -15   5 -10 -40 -19   2 -18 -31 -25   4 -26 -22
[20] -22






mean(TreatmentDiffBP)

[1] -17






TreatmentSubject[which(TreatmentAfterBP < TreatmentPreBP)]

 [6] "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8"  "Subject_10" "Subject_11"
[11] "Subject_12" "Subject_14" "Subject_15" "Subject_16" "Subject_18"
[16] "Subject_19" "Subject_20"

[1] -20.64706

title: Programming in Base R
section: 3. Add a new column to the data frame corresponding to TRUE if the AfterTreatmentBP is less than 120.
text:
3. Add a new column to the data frame corresponding to TRUE if the AfterTreatmentBP is less than 120.


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



TreatmentDF <- TreatmentDF |>
  mutate(TreatmentBPUnder120 = TreatmentAfterBP < 120)
TreatmentDF$TreatmentBPUnder120

 [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE
[13] FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE

title: Programming in Base R
section: 1. Create a new data frame with the placebo experiment.
text:
1. Create a new data frame with the placebo experiment.

PlaceboDF <- data.frame(Subject = 
  PlaceboSubject <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_"), 
  PlaceboBeforeBP = PlaceboBeforeBP <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130), 
  PlaceboAfterBP = PlaceboAfterBP <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124), 
  PlaceboDiffBP = PlaceboDiffBP <- (PlaceboAfterBP - PlaceboBeforeBP) 
)
PlaceboDF <- PlaceboDF |> mutate(PLBPUnder120 = PlaceboAfterBP < 120)

PlaceboDF

      Subject PlaceboBeforeBP PlaceboAfterBP PlaceboDiffBP PLBPUnder120
1   Subject_1             138            105           -33         TRUE
2   Subject_2             135            136             1        FALSE
3   Subject_3             147            123           -24        FALSE
4   Subject_4             117            130            13        FALSE
5   Subject_5             152            134           -18        FALSE
6   Subject_6             134            143             9        FALSE
7   Subject_7             114            135            21        FALSE
8   Subject_8             121            139            18        FALSE
9   Subject_9             131            120           -11        FALSE
10 Subject_10             130            124            -6        FALSE

section: 2. Create and store a list with two elemenets. Treatement and Placebo
text:
2. Create and store a list with two elemenets. Treatement and Placebo

BloodPressure <- list(TreatmentDF, PlaceboDF)

title: Programming in Base R
section: 3. Repeat “3.” for the placebo data frame (within the list).

title: Programming in Base R
text:
Write a function that

-Takes in a list with two data frames in it


- Takes in an R function with the default value being set to “mean”


- Finds the statistic of interest for the pre, post, and diff columns of both data frames

title: Programming in Base R
text:
Blood Pressure Statistics of Interest

Key: BPStat(list name, statistic wanted). The default statistic is “mean”.

ListNames <- c("TreatmentPrePB","TreatmentAfterBP","TreatmentDiffBP", "PlaceboPreBP", "PlaceboAfterBP", "PlaceboDiffBP")
BPStat <- function(x,y = mean){
  list(
    "TreatmentPreBP" = y(x[[1]][[2]]), 
    "TreatmentAfterBP" = y(x[[1]][[3]]), 
    "TreatmentDiffBP" = y(x[[1]][[4]]), 
    "PlaceboPreBP" = y(x[[2]][[2]]), 
    "PlaceboAfterBP" = y(x[[2]][[3]]), 
    "PlaceboDiffBP" = y(x[[2]][[4]])
    )
 }

BPStat(BloodPressure)

$TreatmentPreBP
[1] 129.35

$TreatmentAfterBP
[1] 112.35

$TreatmentDiffBP
[1] -17

$PlaceboPreBP
[1] 131.9

$PlaceboAfterBP
[1] 128.9

$PlaceboDiffBP
[1] -3
